bestBHT.bht: He ate before them, not out of necessity, but to give them undeniable proof of his resurrection. By joining in the common usages of mortals, he showed his selflessness and devotion to their interests. This act of eating proved his reality and dispelled any notion of him being a mere apparition. Believers can draw comfort from this narrative and reflect on his selflessness and love for his followers, as he not only satisfied his own hunger but also shared what remained with them.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: let them see Him doing it: not for His own necessity, but their
John Calvin: Here we perceive...he voluntarily condescends to join in the common usages of mortals.
Thus we see how he disregarded himself, and chose always to be devoted to our interests.
This is the true and pious meditation on this narrative, in which believers may advantageously rest.
Philip Schaff: Luke 24:43. And did eat before them. The mere appearance of eating is out of the question: He really ate, and furnished a proof of His reality.
John Gill: he took both the fish, and the honeycomb, and ate of them before them"
a proof of his being truly risen from the dead, and not a spectre, or apparition
he took the rest, or what remained, and gave it to them
John Wesley: He took it and ate before them — Not that he had any need of food; but to give them still farther evidence.

bhtAttempts.bht: He ate before them, not out of necessity, but to provide them with undeniable proof that He was truly risen from the dead and not a mere spectre or apparition. By voluntarily condescending to join in the common usages of mortals, He disregarded Himself and chose always to be devoted to our interests. This act of eating not only served as a proof of His reality but also exemplified His selflessness and love for His followers. Indeed, believers may find solace and encouragement in meditating on this narrative, where He not only satisfied His own hunger but also took what remained and gave it to them, demonstrating His compassion and care.

He ate before them, not out of necessity, but to give them undeniable proof of his resurrection. By joining in the common usages of mortals, he showed his selflessness and devotion to their interests. This act of eating proved his reality and dispelled any notion of him being a mere apparition. Believers can draw comfort from this narrative and reflect on his selflessness and love for his followers, as he not only satisfied his own hunger but also shared what remained with them.

He ate before them, not out of necessity, but to provide them with undeniable proof that He was truly risen from the dead. By voluntarily joining in the common usages of mortals, He demonstrated His selflessness and dedication to our interests. This act of eating not only served as a proof of His reality but also exemplified His disregard for Himself and constant devotion to our well-being. Believers can find solace and benefit from meditating on this narrative, where He not only satisfied His own hunger but also generously shared what remained with His followers.
